sen.j: 国約憲法（こくやくけんぽう）とは、国民代表の会議によって憲法を作成して君主（日本の場合は天皇）に承認させる手続を経る事で国民と君主間の約束事として位置づけられた憲法のこと。
sen.e: Kokuyaku Kenpo is a constitution that is defined as a rule between citizens and a monarch (an Emperor in Japan) through the procedure of formulating a constitution by a congress representing the public and making a monarch approve it.

Kokuyaku Constitution defined laws that were formulated by representatives of the people and approved by the ruler (in Japan's case it would be the Emperor) and this procedure served as a sort of promise between the ruler and his people.

sen.e: Kokuyaku Constitution defined laws that were formulated by representatives of the people and approved by the ruler (in Japan's case it would be the Emperor) and this procedure served as a sort of promise between the ruler and his people.

sen.j: 自由民権運動最中の1880年頃より、東京日日新聞や朝野新聞などで人権の擁護と天皇制の維持の両立のために、制憲のための会議を招集して憲法草案を作成し、天皇の合意を得られた国約憲法をもって憲法とすべしとの論調が張られ、民権家達にも影響を与えた。
sen.e: From around 1880, during the Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right), the Tokyo Nichinichi Newspaper, the Choya Newspaper and others went for the tone that people should convene a congress for the establishment of a constitution and formulate a draft constitution in order to support the protection of human rights and the maintenance of the Emperor system at the same time, and a Kokuyaku Kenpo approved by the Emperor should be the constitution, which influenced the tribunes.

During the Movement for Liberty and People's rights sometime around 1880, the Tokyo Nichinichi Newspaper, the Choya Newspaper, and other major newspapers claimed that, in order to simultaneous support both the people's rights and Imperial order, a congress of the people should be convened to formulate constitutions drafts, which would be instituted once it met with the Emperor's approval, and this opinion greatly influenced the populace.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味をより分かりやすくために訳文を変えました。
sen.e: During the Movement for Liberty and People's rights sometime around 1880, the Tokyo Nichinichi Newspaper, the Choya Newspaper, and other major newspapers claimed that, in order to simultaneous support both the people's rights and Imperial order, a congress of the people should be convened to formulate constitutions drafts, which would be instituted once it met with the Emperor's approval, and this opinion greatly influenced the populace.

sen.j: 同年の国会期成同盟でも国会開設を前提とした制憲議会確立を求める決議が出され、その準備のために各地で私擬憲法が作成される事になった。
sen.e: In the Kokkai Kisei Domei (League for Founding a National Assembly) of the same year, a resolution seeking the setting up of a congress for the establishment of a constitution presupposed the opening of the National Diet was proposed, and shigi-kenpo (personal draft of constitution) were formulated in various places to prepare for it.

At the National Assembly Association of the same year, it was voted that a constitution-forming body should be established before the opening of the National Diet, and each province began formulating constituion drafts.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味をより分かりやすくために訳文を変えました。
sen.e: At the National Assembly Association of the same year, it was voted that a constitution-forming body should be established before the opening of the National Diet, and each province began formulating constituion drafts.

sen.j: だが、翌年の国会開設の詔書によって憲法は欽定憲法による方針が打ち出されたことによって、国約憲法論は事実上挫折した。
sen.e: However, the following year, an imperial edict of the establishment of the National Diet was issued in which the policy that the constitution would be enacted by the emperor was announced, so the idea of a Kokuyaku Kenpo was virtually thwarted.

However, the following year, an imperial edict at the opening of the National Diet declared that the constitutions would be created by the Emperor, and the idea of a constitution created by the people's representatives never materialized.
